title: Car Depreciation Calculator – Estimate Resale Value Over Time
shortDescription: Estimate your car's resale value and depreciation over time. See yearly value breakdown and total loss in value.
longDescription: Calculate how much your car will depreciate and what it will be worth when you sell it. This calculator estimates resale value based on different depreciation models, including simple annual percentage, first-year drop plus annual rate, or fixed resale value. See year-by-year value breakdown to understand how your car loses value over time. Perfect for planning car purchases, understanding ownership costs, and making informed decisions about when to sell.

inputs.label: Purchase Price
inputs.helpText: The price you paid or will pay for the car

inputs.label: Purchase Type
inputs.helpText: Choose whether the car is new or used

inputs.label: Years Owned
inputs.helpText: How many years you plan to own the car (1-15 years)

inputs.label: Depreciation Model
inputs.helpText: Choose calculation method: simple annual percent, first year drop + annual, or fixed resale value

inputs.label: Annual Depreciation Rate
inputs.helpText: Expected annual depreciation percentage (typically 10-20% for cars)

inputs.label: First Year Drop Rate
inputs.helpText: Percentage value lost in first year (default: 20% for new, 10% for used)

inputs.label: Mileage Per Year
inputs.helpText: Average miles driven per year (optional, for mileage impact calculation)

inputs.label: Apply Mileage Impact
inputs.helpText: Enable to reduce resale value based on high mileage

inputs.label: Fixed Resale Value
inputs.helpText: Override calculation with a specific estimated resale value

howTo: Enter the purchase price of the car
Select whether the car is new or used
Enter how many years you plan to own the car
- Simple Annual Percent: Applies the same rate each year
- First Year Drop + Annual: Larger drop in year 1, then annual rate
- Fixed Resale Value: Enter a specific resale value estimate
Enter the annual depreciation rate (typically 10-20% for cars)
If using first year drop model, enter first year drop rate (defaults provided)
Optionally enter annual mileage and enable mileage impact
Click 'Calculate' to see estimated resale value and depreciation
Review the year-by-year breakdown to see how value changes over time

examples.title: Example 1: New Car $30,000, 5 Years, 15% Annual + First Year 20%
examples.description: A new $30,000 car with first year drop model. Year 1: 20% drop, then 15% annually.
steps: Depreciation model: First Year Drop + Annual

examples.title: Example 2: Used Car $15,000, 3 Years, 10% Annual
examples.description: A used car with simple annual depreciation of 10% per year
steps: Note: Used cars depreciate slower than new cars since most initial value loss has already occurred

examples.title: Example 3: 5 Years Ownership
examples.description: A $25,000 new car owned for 5 years with 15% annual depreciation

examples.title: Example 4: Luxury Car, High Depreciation
examples.description: A $35,000 new luxury car with first year drop model over 5 years
steps: Depreciation model: First Year Drop + Annual
Note: Depreciation is often the largest ownership cost, especially for new luxury cars

examples.title: Example 5: Fixed Resale Value Model
examples.description: A $22,000 car with a specific estimated resale value of $8,000 after 4 years
steps: Note: Fixed resale value model uses linear depreciation for display purposes

faq.question: How does car depreciation work?
faq.answer: Car depreciation is the loss in value over time. New cars lose value fastest in the first year (often 20-30%), then continue depreciating annually (typically 10-20% per year). Depreciation is a non-cash expense but represents real money lost when you sell or trade in your car.

faq.question: What's the difference between new and used car depreciation?
faq.answer: New cars depreciate much faster, especially in the first year (often 20-30% loss). Used cars have already lost most of their initial value, so they depreciate slower (typically 10-15% annually). This is why used cars can be better value - most depreciation has already occurred.

faq.question: What affects resale value?
faq.answer: Many factors affect resale value: vehicle age, mileage, condition, maintenance history, accident history, brand reputation, model popularity, market demand, and economic conditions. High mileage, poor condition, and accident history significantly reduce resale value.

faq.question: Is depreciation linear?
faq.answer: No, depreciation is not linear. Cars lose value fastest in the first few years, then the rate slows. The first year typically sees the largest drop (20-30% for new cars), then annual depreciation of 10-20%. This is why the 'first year drop + annual' model is often more accurate than simple annual percent.

faq.question: How accurate is this estimation?
faq.answer: The calculator provides estimates based on general depreciation patterns. Actual resale value depends on many factors: vehicle condition, mileage, maintenance, market demand, brand, model, and economic conditions. Use it as a planning tool and expect variation. Research actual resale values for your specific vehicle for more accuracy.

faq.question: Should I buy used to avoid depreciation?
faq.answer: Buying used can help avoid the steep first-year depreciation that new cars experience. However, used cars may have higher maintenance costs and shorter remaining lifespan. Consider total cost of ownership, not just depreciation. The calculator helps you compare scenarios.

faq.question: What is a typical depreciation rate?
faq.answer: Typical annual depreciation rates: New cars: 15-25% in first year, then 10-20% annually. Used cars: 10-15% annually. Luxury and high-performance cars often depreciate faster. Economy cars and popular models may hold value better. Research your specific vehicle for more accurate rates.

faq.question: How does mileage affect depreciation?
faq.answer: High mileage significantly reduces resale value. Average is about 12,000 miles per year. Vehicles with much higher mileage (20,000+ miles/year) lose value faster. The calculator can account for mileage impact - high mileage reduces estimated resale value.

faq.question: When is the best time to sell my car?
faq.answer: There's no perfect time, but consider: cars lose value fastest in first 2-3 years, so keeping longer spreads depreciation over more years. However, older cars have higher maintenance costs. Balance depreciation rate, maintenance costs, and your needs. The year-by-year table helps visualize this.

faq.question: Can I reduce depreciation?
faq.answer: You can't stop depreciation, but you can minimize it: keep mileage low, maintain the vehicle well, keep detailed service records, avoid accidents, keep it clean, and choose vehicles with better resale value (popular models, reliable brands). However, depreciation will still occur.

faq.question: What's the difference between the depreciation models?
faq.answer: Simple Annual Percent applies the same rate each year. First Year Drop + Annual applies a larger drop in year 1 (typical for new cars), then annual rate. Fixed Resale Value lets you override with a specific estimate. Choose based on your needs - first year drop is most accurate for new cars.

faq.question: Why is depreciation important?
faq.answer: Depreciation is often the largest cost of car ownership, even larger than fuel for many vehicles. Understanding depreciation helps you make informed decisions about car purchases, when to sell, and total cost of ownership. It's a hidden cost that many people overlook.

faq.question: How do I use the year-by-year table?
faq.answer: The year-by-year table shows how your car's value changes each year. Use it to see when depreciation slows, plan when to sell, and understand the impact of ownership duration. It helps visualize that depreciation is fastest in early years.

faq.question: Does this include other ownership costs?
faq.answer: No, this calculator focuses only on depreciation (loss in value). For total ownership costs including fuel, insurance, maintenance, and depreciation, use our Car Cost of Ownership Calculator.

faq.question: What if I have a specific resale value in mind?
faq.answer: Use the 'Fixed Resale Value' model to override the calculation with your own estimate. This is useful if you have a trade-in offer, dealer quote, or research-based estimate. The calculator will show total depreciation based on your resale value.
